page.title: 03TOAT MONUMENT, PULBOROUGH
page.content: Prominent amongst fields on a hill about 200 feet above sea level is a six sided brick tower three storeys high with a battlemented top. A tablet on the north side indicates that the tower was erected in 1823 in memory of Samuel DRINKALD, who was one of three sons of the then owner of Toat House, John DRINKALD. John was a merchant well known also for his heavy betting at race meetings. "Toat" is said to be of Saxon derivation and means "look-out". The view from the tower is extensive in all directions. Local legend has it that John Drinkald was fond of hunting. When too old to hunt he used to watch the progress of the local hunt from the top of the tower.
